item.title: Solving Polynomials in The Complex Plane
item.description: When working with polynomials, if a polynomial has a solution that has a [[/notes/Complex Numbers|complex part]], then the complex conjugate of this number is also a solution to the polynomial.

item.title: Euler's Identity
item.description: Euler’s identity is really useful when using [[/notes/Polar Coordinates|Polar Coordinates]], it is also especially useful since it applies perfectly well and very intuitively into the [[/notes/Polar form Multiplication|Polar form Multiplication]] rules.

item.title: Polar form Multiplication
item.description: Multiplying in [[/notes/Polar Coordinates|Polar Coordinates]] causes a bunch of shit to go haywire. Here are some rules: for two given polar points $z = r(cos(\theta)+isin(\theta))$ and $w = s(cos(\phi)+isin(\phi))$

item.title: Polar Coordinates
item.description: Polar forms are a special way of representing points in the 2d plane. Any point in the 2D plane is defined by its rotation and the distance from origin in that rotation.

item.title: Complex Numbers
item.description: These numbers are complex, they are hard to understand, just like your ex. Except they don’t sleep with your best friend and give you chlamidia.

item.title: Double Integrals Over General Functions
item.description: Calculating [[/notes/Double Integrals Over Rectangles|Double Integrals Over Rectangles]] is nice, but do you know what is nicer? Calculating double integrals over any area.

item.title: Multivariable Function as Product of Two Functions
item.description: If you can write a [[/notes/Multivariable Functions|multivariable function]] as the product of two functions, one of which is defined by $x$ and the other $y$, [[/notes/Double Integrals Over Rectangles|integrating]] it becomes much easier.

item.title: Fubini's Theorem
item.description: Fubini’s theorem for [[/notes/Double Integrals Over Rectangles|Double Integrals Over Rectangles]] is that for a rectangle $D = [a,b] \times [c,d]$ the integral can be written as:

item.title: Double Integrals Over Rectangles
item.description: When the $\Delta A$ approaches zero while calculating the [[/notes/3D Riemann Sum on Rectangles|3D Riemann Sum on Rectangles]], it can be written as an integral.

item.title: 3D Riemann Sum on Rectangles
item.description: When you want to calculate the area taken up by a [[/notes/Multivariable Functions|multivariable function]] in a rectangle defined by the set of points $[a,b] \times [c,d]$ which can also be written as the rectangle drawn between the points $(a,c)$ and $(b,d)$, we can split up the rectangle into smaller rectangles of area $A$.

item.title: Binomial Series
item.description: Binomial series are a special type of [[/notes/Power Series|Power Series]] which are used to describe functions of the form $(a+x)^r$. Even though a power series can be calculated for every single form of this function, it is often easier to calculate the power series of $(1-x)^r$ which is

item.title: Taylor Series
item.description: Taylor series are [[/notes/Power Series|Power Series]] which can describe a function $f$, which is continously differentiable. The taylor series of a function $f$ at the point $a$ is defined as:

item.title: Power Series As Functions
item.description: Since power series are defined relevant to a value $x$. We can define some properties for two series $f(x) = \sum a_nx^n$ for $|x|<R_1$ and $g(x) = \sum b_nx^n$ for $|x|< R_2$:

item.title: MinMax Points in Multivariable Functions
item.description: [[/notes/Multivariable Functions|Multivariable Functions]] have minima and maxima points, which can be found using [[/notes/Critical Points Multivariable Functions|critical points]]. After finding them, in order to check whether they are minima, maxima or saddle points, we can either apply the second [[/notes/Partial Derivatives|partial derivate]] test which goes like:

item.title: Critical Points Multivariable Functions
item.description: A crtitical point in [[/notes/Multivariable Functions|Multivariable Functions]] are stationary points in the graph. i.e. $f_x(a,b) = f_y(a,b) = 0$. Or if the derivative of a function does not exist at that point.

item.title: Multivalued Function Gradient
item.description: [[/notes/Multivariable Functions|Multivariable Functions]]’ derivatives change according to which way you move. However, the gradient of a multivariable function is basically the direction/[[/notes/Vectors|vector]] in which the gradient is maximal.

item.title: Directional Derivative
item.description: The directional derivative of a [[/notes/Multivariable Functions|multivariable function]] is the rate of change of a function $f(x,y)$ at the direction of a unit vector $u$.

item.title: Clairaut's Theorem
item.description: When calculating the second derivative of a function $f(x,y)$, $f_xy = f_yx$. i.e. The order of derivation doesn’t matter. This can also be represented as:

item.title: Linearization of Multivariable Functions
item.description: In single variable functions, it was possible to draw a tangent line that touches the function at a certain point $a$.

item.title: Partial Derivatives
item.description: When dealing with [[/notes/Multivariable Functions|Multivariable Functions]], it is hard to talk about regular derivations. Instead, we calculate the partial derivatives of the function according to a certain variable.

item.title: Multivariable Functions
item.description: Multivariable functions are functions defined in the domain $\mathbb{R}^2$ and written as $f(x,y) = z$. These functions’ graphs are three dimensional and hard to plot, so they are often projected to the 2D plane using [[/notes/Level Lines|contours]].

item.title: Power Series
item.description: Power series are a special kind of [[/notes/Series|Series]] that can be written in the form: $$ \sum_{n=0}^\infty = c_n(x-a)^n = c_0 + c_1(x-a) + c_2(x-a)^2 … $$

item.title: Limit Comparison Test
item.description: Similar to the [[/notes/Comparison Test|Comparison Test]], given two series, $\sum a_n$ and $\sum b_n$ all with positive terms, calculating the limit:

item.title: Ratio Test
item.description: Let $\sum a_n$ be a series such that $a_n \neq 0$. Then, calculating the limit $$ \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{|a_{n+1}|}{|a_n|} = L $$

item.title: Comparison Test
item.description: This test is similar to [[/notes/The Squeeze Theorem - Limits|the squeeze theorem]]. Given two series, $\sum a_n$ $\sum b_n$ with positive terms, if $\sum b_n$ is convergent and $a_n \leq b_n$ for all $n$, then $\sum a_n$ converges.

item.title: Alternating Series Test
item.description: An alternating series is basically a series whose terms’ signs are changing regularly. They often have the form $$ \sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^n a_n $$

item.title: Divergence Test
item.description: The divergence test is pretty much the least useless one. All it does is that it checks if a [[/notes/Series|Series]] is not [[/notes/Convergent Series|convergent]].

item.title: Geometric Series
item.description: If a [[/notes/Sequences|sequence]] a can be written as: $$ a_n = cr^n $$ Than this is sequence forms the geometric [[/notes/Series|Series]]:

item.title: P-Series
item.description: P-Series(Power [[/notes/Series|Series]]) are a special kind of series such that: $$ \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{x^p} $$ This type of series has the property that it is divergent when $p\leq1$ and [[/notes/Convergent Series|convergent]] otherwise.

item.title: Convergence Testing Of Series
item.description: There are several methods that can be used in order to test whether a series is convergent. [[/notes/Divergence Test|Divergence Test]] The least useful of them all [[/notes/Alternating Series Test|Alternating Series Test]] A test to check whether alternating series converge [[/notes/Comparison Test|Comparison Test]] A test similar to the squeeze theorem in limits [[/notes/Limit Comparison Test|Limit Comparison Test]] Similar to the comparison test, except it involves limits [[/notes/Ratio Test|Ratio Test]] A test which eventually leads us to power series

item.title: Series
item.description: Series are closely related to [[/notes/Sequences|Sequences]]. Basically a series is the sum of the first $k$ elements in a given series.

item.title: Sequences
item.description: Sequences are basically lists real numbers. In a sequence, there is a real number for each postive integer. So, sequences can also be defined as functions such that $f(n): \mathbb{Z}^+\implies\mathbb{Q}$.

item.title: Horizontal Asymptote
item.description: Horizontal asymptotes occur when a function approaches to a certain value as x goes to infinity. So, there can be 2 different horizontal asymptotes at max.

item.title: Vertical Asymptotes
item.description: Vertical asymptotes are asymptotes where the value of a function $f(x)$ is undefined at a certain point a and the function goes to infinity as x approaches x.

item.title: Cancelling Common Factors
item.description: When you have a function such that $f(x) = \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$ where $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$ are polynomials and $P(a) = Q(a) = 0$ where a is in the domain of x, we can solve the limit $\lim_{x\to a}$ by cancelling out a common factor between $P$ and $Q$.
